pageProps.body:
Graph Analysis

Similarity Graphs and Laplacians

From Graph Laplacians
Go to text →

Let G=(V,E)G= (V,E)G=(V,E) be a graph and w:E−>R+0w:E->R^{+0}w:E−>R+0 be a weight function. Then let the degree matrix D be the diagonal matrix with Di,i=∑j∈Ew(i,j)D_{i,i}=\sum_{j\in E} w(i,j)Di,i​=∑j∈E​w(i,j). Let the corresponding adjacency matrix be Ai,j=wi,jA_{i,j} = w_{i,j}Ai,j​=wi,j​ Then the unnormalized Graph Laplacian is given by:

L=D−AL = D-AL=D−A

In the unweighted case, all edges have a weight of 1, and non-edges have a weight of 0.

We can show that LLL is positive semidefinite,that is, for any vector vvv in RnR^{n}Rn, vTLvv^TLvvTLv is non-negative.

Normalized Versions

Symmetric:

Lsym=D−1/2LD−1/2L_{sym} = D^{-1/2}LD^{-1/2}Lsym​=D−1/2LD−1/2

Random Walk Laplacian:

LRW=D−1LL_{RW} = D^{-1}LLRW​=D−1L

Normalized Laplacians

I−D−1WI-D^{-1}WI−D−1W - random walk matrix.

From Spectral Clustering
Go to text →

Spectral Clustering: ^ spectral Clustering

Let us have nnn datapoints and some dissimilarity function on them. We would like to compute a Clustering on them. we can use graph cuts on a weighted undirected similarity graph G=(1,2,...,n,W)G = ({1,2,...,n},W)G=(1,2,...,n,W).

cut(C1,C2)=∑i,j∈E,i∈C1,j∈C2wi,jcut(C_1,C_2) = \sum_{i,j\in E, i \in C_1,j\in C_2} w_{i,j}cut(C1​,C2​)=∑i,j∈E,i∈C1​,j∈C2​​wi,j​ where C1,C2C_1,C_2C1​,C2​ are arbitrary (disjoint) sets of nodes.

cut(C1,C2,...,Ck)=∑i=1..kcut(Ci,Ciˉ)cut(C_1,C_2,...,C_k) = \sum_{i = 1..k} cut(C_i,\bar{C_i})cut(C1​,C2​,...,Ck​)=∑i=1..k​cut(Ci​,Ci​ˉ​) where Ciˉ\bar{C_i}Ci​ˉ​ is the complement of C1C_1C1​.

We would like to minimize a normalized version of this cut:

ratio−cut(C1,C2,...,Ck)=∑i=1..kcut(Ci,Ciˉ)/∣Ci∣ratio-cut(C_1,C_2,...,C_k) = \sum_{i = 1..k} cut(C_i,\bar{C_i})/|C_i|ratio−cut(C1​,C2​,...,Ck​)=∑i=1..k​cut(Ci​,Ci​ˉ​)/∣Ci​∣

The reason of doing this is that otherwise we might get too many splits in practice (maybe there's some theoretical reason as well)

Approximation Via Laplacian Eigenvectors

If we define the clusterings as normalized indicator vectors hhh on the graph, they are orthonormal.
They also minimize the expression ratio−cut(C1,...Ck)=Σi=1..KhkTLhkratio-cut (C_1,...C_k) = \Sigma_{i=1..K} h_k^TLh_kratio−cut(C1​,...Ck​)=Σi=1..K​hkT​Lhk​.

Were they not to identity, it would correspond to computing the eigenvectors.

Which eigenvectors do we take? If the graph was disconnected, there would be multiple eigenvectors, corresponding to the eigenvalue 0. So we take instead the kkk eigenvectors,corresponding to the kkk smallest eigenvalues.

This would gives us a new data representation of the graph, to which we can apply say Clustering k-means.
